name: hydrurga-leptonyx
definition: The leopard seal is the second largest species of seal in the Antarctic.
description:
Leopard seals are by far the largest of the Antarctic seals.

Their bodies are sinuous and their powerful jaws open widely to show extremely long canine teeth.

They have a large, reptile-like head with a long, flexible neck.

The overall body shape is long and slender, which makes them very agile when in the water.

Their coloring is different dorsally to ventrally, as their back is dark gray, their underside is silvery gray, and there are dark and light spots over the entire body.

The coat of juveniles is much softer and thicker, and has a dorsal stripe, with a light gray underside scattered with dark spots.

Although males and females are similar in appearance, which is unusual for a seal, females are slightly larger than males.

Leopard seals can be found in the circumpolar area in the Antarctic pack ice, or associated ice bergs and ice floes.

A small number are found year round on the nearby sub-Antarctic islands just beyond the pack ice.

Some have also been observed around coasts as far north as South Africa, South America, Australia and New Zealand.

Leopard seal is a carnivore and vicious predator.

It hunts and eats fish, squids, shellfish, penguins and other species of seal.

Leopard seal hunts in shallow water; it does not dive deeply.

Despite large size and fearsome nature of leopard seal, nearly 50% of its diet is based on the krill.

Leopard seal only natural predator is the killer whale.

Leopard seals are polygynous, one male mating with multiple females.

Gestation lasts for 8 to 9 months, and a single pup is born.

Females generally stock up on food prior to giving birth, which takes place in a hole amongst the pack ice.

Pups are fed on rich fatty milk, which enables them to grow quickly.

Within a month a pup molts its first coat and can go to sea.

The mother protects her pup until it can take care of itself; male seals do not take part in parental care.

Leopard seals are diurnal, meaning they are active during the day and sleep at night.

They are solitary, both on the ice and at sea, with groups only forming by temporary mating pairs or by pairs of mothers and pups.

They are graceful swimmers, and use powerful, long simultaneous strokes with their flippers.

They can stay underwater for 15 to 30 minutes, sometimes sleeping under water and coming to the surface for air without waking up.

Leopard seals are usually quiet on the ice.

When underwater they make trills, grunts, growling noises and low frequency moans.

facts.name: Can reach 68 kilometers per hour
facts.value: Leopard seal is graceful swimmer that can reach the speed of 68 kilometers per hour.

facts.name: Sexual maturity at 2 to 7 years
facts.value: Males reach sexual maturity at the age of 2 to 7 years, females at the age of 4 to 6 years.

facts.name: Carnivore and vicious predator
facts.value: Leopard seal is a carnivore and vicious predator. It feeds on a wide range of prey including cephalopods, other pinnipeds, krill, birds and fish.

facts.name: Small clawed water worker
facts.value: Scientific name of leopard seal is "Hydrurga leptonyx", which means "small clawed water worker".

facts.name: Ambush predator
facts.value: Leopard seal is an ambush predator. It waits the prey hidden under the ice packs and grabs them in a blink of an eye the moment they enter the water. Adélie penguin is often on the menu and it is usually swallowed in 4 to 7 minutes.

facts.name: Young leopard seals migrate
facts.value: Young leopard seals migrate between June and October toward the north to find better sources of food, while adults reside near the ice packs all year round.

facts.name: Can reach 3.5 meters in length
facts.value: Leopard seal can reach 2.4 to 3.5 meters in length and between 200 and 600 kilograms of weight. Females are larger than males.

facts.name: One of the top predators in the ocean
facts.value: Leopard seal is one of the top predators in the ocean. Killer whale and large sharks are the only natural enemies of these seals.

facts.name: Built for hunting
facts.value: Leopard seal has elongated head, long, flexible neck, elongated body and long, pointed front flippers. It has strong jaws, long canine teeth and interlocking molars designed to extract the krill from the sea water.

facts.name: Pulls its neck backward before the strike
facts.value: Leopard seal pulls its long flexible neck backward (just like a snake) before the strike.

facts.name: Survive 26 years in the wild
facts.value: Leopard seal can survive about 26 years in the wild.

facts.name: Black spots resembling the leopard
facts.value: Leopard seal has silver grey or dark grey (nearly black) skin on the back and whitish silver skin on the front side of the body. Black spots on the body of leopard seal resemble the spots on a leopard's body, hence the name. Thick layer of blubber under the skin prevents freezing in the cold water.

facts.name: Mating season in the summer
facts.value: Mating season of leopard seals takes place during the summer. Males produce bird-like trills and low haunting moans to attract females.

facts.name: Pregnancy lasts 9 months
facts.value: Pregnancy lasts 9 months and ends with single baby (pup). Young leopard seal depends on the mother's milk until the age of one month.

related.definition: The ringed seal , also known as the jar seal, as netsik or nattiq by the Inuit, is an earless seal inhabiting the Arctic and sub-Arctic regions.
The harbor  seal is a true seal found along temperate and Arctic marine coastlines of the Northern Hemisphere.
The southern elephant seal  is one of the two species of elephant seals.
The Mediterranean monk seal  is a monk seal belonging to the family Phocidae.
The hooded seal  is a large phocid found only in the central and western North Atlantic, ranging from Svalbard in the east to the  Gulf of St. Lawrence.
The crabeater seal s a true seal with a circumpolar distribution around the coast of Antarctica.
